ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture available, live section
live virtual lecture and live virtual discussion section
Virtual live discussion section in addition to virtual live lectures
Virtual section

Sometimes we used recorded lectures when there were issues with time commitment. Usually, however, we used in-person lectures (which were recorded in case you couldn't attend class) and a combination of readings (and some short videos) online for weekly work.
None.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: General knowledge of architecture history
I leave this class with a very rudimentary understanding of some of the trends in architectural history.

Knowledge: a general understanding of the history of architecture from Antiquity to the Baroque, as well as some of the potential pitfalls that currently exist in how this subject is taught in Western academia

Skills: critical thinking, historical research, reading, writing

Insights: how the history of architecture from Antiquity to the Baroque continues to be relevant in contemporary society, how architecture expresses and influences the societies within which it exists

This course completely challenged the way I view the world and its relationship with architectural space; despite the course's title of "antiquity to Baroque," the scope of material was incredibly relevant to a contemporary student, with constant connections being made to modernity in quite unexpected ways, every single lecture.
I learned a lot about the meaning of architecture and how to think about it in its historical context in addition to its physical.
Learned a lot about the history of architecture, mostly Western architecture but I suppose history is still catching up. I appreciate the awareness of this though, during class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very abundant knowledge and broad horizons. More guest lectures with different views would be preferable.

This course is far too theoretical. It assumes a fairly robust knowledge of architectural theory and terminology never listed as a prerequisite. The Professor is clearly brilliant but devotes the lecture to too many disparate strands, few of which obviously relate to the basics of what a given civilization or style engaged with or contributed to architecture. As a result, the nuances in which he revels are fairly inaccessible.
In addition, there was no clear expectations of what form the papers should take. Despite several TA meetings, I learned only in feedback on my first paper what the expected components were.

Strengths: provided a critical approach to the subject matter, tying historical subjects into contemporary problems; allowed students to gain a high-level understanding of the subject matter while providing opportunities to investigate deeper; challenged students to develop their own points of view through research and discussion

Weaknesses: curriculum followed the conventional timeline (as seen in the textbook) which was at times in tension with the intent of the class to question the validity of this very timeline (though the efforts of the professor to begin challenging what content is taught and how content is structured over the course of the semester are appreciated)

This course is exceptional. I believe that there was a high level of engagement required from each student, especially in discussion section, but from start to finish the readings, lectures, and discussions were truly fascinating. There were no real weaknesses.

This course had terrific readings, and Professor Dugdale was clearly very intellectual and engaged in the topic. I, personally, was expecting a little more of an introductory course in terms of learning about techniques, terms, styles, etc. That said, what we got instead was still very intriguing!
Strengths were that it was a very welcoming class for those who were more familiar with architecture and those who weren't.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A structured layout in lectures would be helpful to catch up with the content in virtual context.
Lecture format worked.

The virtual office hours were a good way to make communication with the professor more accessible to students, though perhaps there could have been some more flexibility with the times. The virtual nature of lectures and discussion sections were successful as a whole, though in-person interaction would have still been preferred (given different circumstances, of course). Perhaps lectures and discussion sections could have leaned more heavily on being creative with the virtual platform (instead of just moving lectures/discussions into an online space). Guest lectures were very much appreciated though, and suggest that other guests from even further away could be brought in for future lectures.

Professor Dugdale did an exceptional job cultivating an engaging, thoughtful classroom even within a virtual space. Discussion sections were highly effective due to the fact that each reading was presented by students every week, so each student's discussion and responsibility to the material was inherent to success on a weekly basis. Though this meant a more serious workload and constant participation, it paid off immensely in the online format.
the course could be more engaging, and the instructors less harsh in their grading (considering the circumstances)
I think the lecture practices over Zoom were as good as possible.
Communication with the professor and TA was very open and available.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes if you want to establish a basic understanding of architecture history around the world.
Take this course if you ALREADY have a strong background in architecture. If not, it will likely go over your head.

I would highly recommend this course to another student. I thoroughly enjoyed the class's approach to a topic that can be quite dry and found myself intellectually engaged by the content and assignments of the class.

I would absolutely recommend this course. There is nothing about this course that feels antiquated or lofty, despite the daunting title, and I firmly believe that even a student with no background or explicit interest in architecture would find this class to truly change the way you think on a regular basis. I found myself constantly gushing about these lectures to my family and friends -- it was the highlight of my semester.

I would recommend this course to another student ONLY IF they understand that this is a very intellectual and idea-driven course. I signed up for the course thinking that it would be an introduction to architecture through history: exploring the practices, techniques, styles, etc. over time. Instead, it's very much a course about the IDEA of architectural history. Lectures are generally a case study which revolve around a single building from a given historical period and discuss how that building--and other related structures--change our conception of the meaning of architecture vis-a-vis its historical context. This is VERY interesting, but it was not what I was expecting, and as a student with no experience I felt like I couldn't get everything out of the course, because I didn't understand the basic principles.
Yes, if you are interested in the content.
